thread.title: Mayor withdraws support for Civic Square project amid...
thread.title_full: Mayor withdraws support for Civic Square project amid... | www.kirotv.com

author: kirotv.com
title: Mayor withdraws support for Civic Square project amid...
text:
Seattle Mayor Ed Murray has withdrawn his support for the developers of the Civic Square project, he announced at a news conference Wednesday.
The announcement comes after a City Council candidate claimed a developer tried to "blackmail" him over the project.
Civic Square is that big hole in the ground next to City Hall. It was sold to Triad Capital Partners eight years ago for a skyscraper project that languished during the great recession.
City Council candidate Jon Grant is the former director of the Seattle Tenants union. He says a senior vice president of Triad wanted him to get the Tenants Union to end their lawsuit against the project.
He says Brett Allen indicated that he could make plans for a $200,000 expenditure against Grant go away, if Grant would help.
Allen apologized Tuesday for what he called an "inappropriate" message.
I am extremely disappointed by these questionable actions – they do not represent the values of our city. Seattle expects and deserves better," Murray said Wednesday.
Murray said the city has no intention of moving ahead with the project. The city's contract with Triad expires at the end of this year and the contract will not be extended, Murray said.
“In the meantime, I have asked the City Attorney to explore whether there are any grounds to terminate the contract in a responsible way that does not adversely affect the City or taxpayers, said Murray.
